name:
Gamification Strategy
Compass
description:
The Gamification Strategy Compass (GSC) is a taxonomy to describe, guide, and analyze gamification strategies. 
It is intended to support practitioners in systematically documenting and reflecting on their
gamification strategies and to help researchers compare and analyze different gamification strategies. 
To navigate the compass, klick on the different elements of the chart to zoom into each 
level and click on the central element after zooming, to return to the previous level.

name: Context and Organization
description:
This Dimension includes all aspects that may influence 
the gamification strategy and are defined
or impacted by the organizational structure.

name: Organizational Goal
description:
The organizational goal can also be called a business incentive. Each organization has one or
more goals they want to achieve. These can be long-term, mid-term, or short-term and can be
more broad (e.g., financial profit) or specific (e.g., increase the number of users by 10%).

name: Resources
description:
The resources that an organization has and assigns to a project set the potential scope of a project.
For gamification research, it is reasonable to document information on these aspects to ensure
the comparability of approaches.

name: Team
description:
The team structure has a significant impact on which methods and processes are available. For
example, some methods require a minimum number of team members or specific skills.

name: Size
description:
When documenting a project, one may give the exact number of team members or provide one
of the following to report the team size.

name: Expertise/Roles
description: The expertise of team members can influence the project's possible approaches and outcomes.

name: Other
description: If you miss a specific role which is important for your project approach, please suggest its addition.

name: Time
description:
The time available impacts the scope of the project, which, in turn, impacts the project and
gamification goals and determines which gamification frameworks and methods are feasible.
When reporting a project, one may give the exact time needed.

name: Budget
description:
The budget has an impact on the scope of the project, which, in turn, impacts the project and
gamification goals and determines which gamification frameworks and methods are feasible.

name: Technologies/Tools
description:
Sometimes, organizations dictate which technologies (e.g., programming languages) and
tools (e.g., project management tools) are allowed, which can influence the choice of
gamification method. Conversely, a method may require specific tools, potentially
leading to changes in the tools used within an organization (e.g., a specific evaluation instrument). 
Because of the almost endless number of possible technologies and tools on the market,
the GSC does not provide a list at this point. This only serves as a reminder, to check
to compatibility of your gamification strategy with the available technologies and tools.

name: Application Domain
description:
The thematic topic in which the gamification project takes place. This can be more broad (e.g.,
education) or specific (e.g., Massive Open Online Courses).

name: Other
description: If you miss another application domain, please suggest its addition.

name: Ethics
description:
Besides general ethical considerations that should be taken into account for every project (e.g.,
privacy), some effects of gamification may raise additional ethical concerns and have to be 
considered separately (e.g., manipulation).

name: Other
description: If you miss another ethical consideration, please suggest its addition.

name: Project Strategy
description:
This dimension includes all aspects determined by the surrounding project. These aspects are not
necessarily influenced by the decision-makers responsible for gamification. However, they can
still affect the choice of gamification strategy.

name: Project Goal
description:
Every project has some kind of goal (e.g., teaching a skill or organizing something). This project
goal needs to be considered when choosing the gamification strategy, which should support the
project goal. As each project goal is individual we give only project goal categories.
A project may have goals from several categories

name: Capability Creation
description: The project expands the space of what is possible for individuals, groups, or organizations.

name: Knowledge & Skill Formation
description: The project aims to impart specific knowledge or skills to individuals or groups.

name: Process Execution
description: The project results in a system that actively performs, replaces, or directly supports concrete tasks or decisions.

name: Optimization
description:
The project aims to improve the performance of an existing processor activity along defined dimensions (e.g.,
efficiency, quality, speed).

name: Control & Assurance
description:
The project is intended to ensure, enforce, or safeguard predefined acceptable states, preventing or detecting
deviations

name: Observation & Feedback
description:
The project primarily aims to generate information, measurements, or transparency about states, behavior, or
performance, without directly altering them.

name: Behavior & Motivation Shaping
description:
The project is designed to influence human behavior, decisions, or motivation through incentives, feedback,
or persuasive mechanisms.

name: Structural Transformation
description:
produces lasting changes to organizational structures, roles, decision logics, or system configurations,
resulting in a new stable organizational state.

name: Other
description: If your project goal does not fit into any of these categories, please suggest an addition.

name: Theoretical Foundation
description:
The project may build upon a specific theoretical foundation, such as a learning theory. Any
gamification theory that is applied must not conflict with this theoretical foundation.

name: Framework
description:
A project may use one or more frameworks (e.g., project management frameworks). A gamification
framework can be one of these frameworks but is found seperately under "gamification framework" in the "Gamification
Strategy" Dimension. It is important that the gamification framework does not conflict with any of the other frameworks
applied in the project.

name: Other
description: Because of the large number of possible frameworks, we only provide a few established examples. If you miss a specific important framework, please suggest its addition.

name: Gamification Strategy
description:
This dimension includes all aspects related to the actual implementation of gamification, often
referred to as the “Gamification Approach.” The gamification strategy outlines the holistic
process of implementing and integrating gamification into a project, from concept to testing. It is
embedded within the overall project strategy and the organizational context.

name: Gamification Goal
description:
The gamification goal should support the project goal. For example, a learning application has
the goal of teaching something, while the gamification goal would be something such as
motivating the learners to keep learning.

name: Other
description: If you miss another gamification goal, please suggest its addition.

name: Gamification Theory
description:
The gamification theory is the theoretical foundation of the gamification strategy. It should also
be the basis of or compatible with the gamification framework. It can be derived from a general
theoretical foundation (e.g., a learning theory) and may be some form of model. Gamification
theories are highly theoretical and do not provide clear guidance to designers for choosing the
right set of game elements.

name: Model
description:
A gamification theory that is some form of theoretical model. Models are abstractions that are
supposed to represent complex contexts. It includes specification of the concepts, relationships,
and rules within the concept.

name: Deterding's Definition of Gamification
description: The use of game design elements in non-game contexts.

name: Werbach's (Re)defining Gamification
description: The process of making activities more game-like

name: Huotari and Hamari's definition of gamification
description: A process of enhancing a service with affordances for gameful experiences in order to support user's overall value creation.

name: Gamification Framework
description:
A structure intended to guide or support the design and integration of gamification. It predominantly
is used to choose specific game elements. It may also be called a “gamification design
framework.” It should build upon a gamification theory and can include tailoring and evaluation
methods. A gamification framework has several attributes (e.g., level of guidance). It can
recommend specific tools and techniques and is part of the gamification strategy.

name: A Framework for Success. Di Tommasso (2011)
description: description value

name: Six steps to Gamification. Werbach and Hunter (2012)
Gamification Design Process. Marache-Francisco and Brangie (2013)
Francisco-Aparicio et al. framework (2013) Gamification: analysis and application.
A moral framework for taking responsibility. Versteeg (2013)
A Framework for Sustainable Gamification Impact. AlMarshedi (2015)
Player Centered Design Methodology. J. Kumar (2013) Gamification at Work: Designing Engaging Business Software
Role-Motivation-Interaction Framework. Gears et al. (2013) Gamification in business: Designing motivating solutions to problem situations
A framework for gamification suited for marketing. Julius and Salo (2013)
A Framework for Designing Gamification in the Enterprise. N. Kumar (2013)
Other
description: If you miss a specific important gamification framework, please suggest its addition.

name: Tailoring
description:
All impact factors that need to be considered for customizing the gamification to the users are
sorted into this category.

name: Tailoring Focus
description:
Since it is impossible to take everything into account when customizing gamification for users,
the tailoring should focus on certain points. These focus points consider some aspect of the users
(e.g., characteristics, player typology, or demographics).

name: Player Typology
description:
Different player typologies have been developed to categorize users based on their gaming
preferences and behaviors.

name: Four Student Profiles of Barata et al.
Five Player Roles of Borges et al.
Other
description: If you miss a specific important player typology, please suggest its addition.

name: Personality Traits
description:
Personality traits can influence how users interact with gamified systems and what
motivates them.

name: Other
description: If you miss a specific important personality trait model, please suggest its addition.

name: Other
description: If you miss another tailoring focus, please suggest its addition.

name: Tailoring Methods
description:
Various methods are available to achieve some form of customization for the users (e.g., adaptive
gamification).

name: Adaptive Gamification
description:
Adaptive gamification dynamically adjusts game elements and mechanics based on user data and
behavior to enhance engagement and effectiveness.

name: Other
description: If you miss another adaptive gamification method, please suggest its addition.

name: Test
description:
All impact factors that need to be considered in the testing phase are sorted into this category.
This includes evaluation as well as validation.

name: Evaluation Dimensions
description:
Aspects that need to be considered when evaluating the gamification. Can overlap with the
evaluation of the overarching project (e.g., user experience) but can also be more specific to the
gamification (e.g., attractiveness of the game elements).

name: Other
description: If you miss another evaluation dimension, please suggest its addition.

name: Evaluation Methods
description:
Methods that evaluate one or more evaluative dimensions. These check how well the gamification
works or how effective it is.

name: A/B Testing
description:
A/B testing, also known as split testing, is a method of comparing two versions of a webpage
or app against each other to determine which one performs better.

name: Surveys/Questionnaires
description:
Surveys and questionnaires are structured tools used to collect data from participants about
their experiences, perceptions, and attitudes towards the gamified system. They offer a
systematic way to gather quantitative and qualitative feedback, enabling researchers
to assess various aspects of user engagement, satisfaction, and the overall effectiveness of
the gamification elements implemented. Some Questionnaires can help asssessing a specific KPI.

name: Flow State Scale-2. Jackson et al. (2002)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Flow
 Designed to assess flow experiences in physical activity within a particular event.

name: Game experience Questionnaire. Ijsselsteijn et al. (2013)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Game Experience (Immersion, Flow, Competence, Positive and Negative
Affect, Tension, and Challenge), psychological and behavioral involvement
 Designed to be administered directly after the gaming session, consisting of 3 Modules.

name: Dispositional Flow State Scale-2. Jackson et al. (2002)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Flow
 Designed to assess flow experiences the frequency of flow experiences in chosen physical activity in general

name: Q sorts questionnaire from Stephenson (1953)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: User Preferences
 A qualitative method to prioritize people's preferences regarding certain topics. For example, specific gamification elements.

name: User Experience Questionnaire (UEQ). Laugwitz et al. (2008)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: User Experience (Attractiveness, Perspicuity, Efficiency, Dependability,
Stimulation, Novelty)
 A standardized questionnaire to measure the user experience of interactive products.

name: System Usability Scale (SUS). Brooke (1996)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Usability
 A tool for measuring the usability. It consists of a 10-item questionnaire with five
response options for respondents; from Strongly agree to Strongly disagree.

name: UEQ+. Schrepp et al. (2017)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: User Experience with 27 flexible scales
 A modular questionnaire to measure the user experience of interactive products. It
offers a flexible approach to measure the UX aspects that are relevant for
each product individually.

name: Gameful Experience Questionnaire (GAMEFULQUEST). Högberg et al. (2019)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Gameful Experience (Accomplishment, Challenge, Competition,
Guidance, Immersion, Playfulness, Social Experience)
 A questionnaire to assess the perceived gamefulness of a system.

name: Single Ease Question (SEQ). Sauro (2011)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Ease of use
 A one-question survey to measure the perceived ease of completing a task with a system.

name: Usability Metric for User Experience (UMUX). Finstad (2010)
description:
Evaluated Dimensions: Usability
 A four item questionnaire to measure perceived usability.

name: Other
description: If you miss another survey/questionnaire, please suggest its addition.

name: Other
description: If you miss another evaluation method, please suggest its addition.

name: Validation Methods
description:
Methods that validate the finished gamification. These check if the gamification goal was
achieved. Can be combined with the validation of the project goal.
